questions.text: A 3-year-old girl is brought in by her mother due to failure to thrive and easy fatigability. Examination reveals severe anemia, splenomegaly, and jaundice. The patient's family history includes an unspecified "blood problem." Hemoglobin electrophoresis is normal, and a complete blood count (CBC) shows normocytic anemia. Peripheral blood smear demonstrates numerous abnormal erythrocytes, including spiculated cells. Given these findings and the presence of an enzyme deficiency leading to anemia, what is the most common enzyme deficiency associated with this presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pyruvate kinase deficiency

 

Option D:

 

Pyruvate kinase deficiency (PKD) is an erythrocyte enzymopathy involving the glycolytic pathway.

 

Erythrocytes have evolved without oxidative phosphorylation to form adenosine triphosphate (ATP), the compound essential for providing the erythrocyte energy.

 

Clinical features:

 

Mild form of PKD; May appear to have no symptoms at all.

 

Severe form of PKD Symptoms include:

  • Chills Fatigue
  • Earlier in life symptoms tend to be detected
  • Pallor, dark urine and enlarged spleen

 

Biochemical findings of hemolytic anemia;

  • Elevated indirect bilirubin levels
  • Reduced Haptoglobin
  • Elevated total reticulocyte count
  • Elevated serum LDH

 

Diagnosis of PKD

  1. Measuring the amount of pyruvate kinase in red blood cells
  2. If there is a family history, mutation analysis could be done to determine carrier status of an individual

 

Medical care and Treatment

  • In the severe cases
  • multiple blood transfusions may be required
  • Splenectomy.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency will results in anemia with Smear findings of `Bite cells.

 

Option B: Glucose-6-Phosphatase deficiency will results in the Type 1 Glycogen storage disorder.

 

Option C: Pyruvate dehydrogenase complex (PDC) deficiency will results in the Lactic acidosis, ataxia and retardation.

 

Educational objective:

 

Pyruvate kinase deficiency is an enzyme disorder that leads to hemolytic anemia by affecting the glycolytic pathway in red blood cells, resulting in insufficient ATP production and decreased cell survival. The clinical presentation can include failure to thrive, severe anemia, splenomegaly, and jaundice. The presence of bizarre erythrocytes, including spiculated cells on the peripheral smear, is consistent with hemolytic anemia.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 490 – Page No 10062-10065

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought in by her anxious mother due to a significantly enlarged abdomen and recurrent episodes of weakness, sweating, and pallor, which resolve after eating. The child has a history of delayed developmental milestones and poor academic performance. Physical examination reveals an enlarged, firm liver. Laboratory tests show hypoglycemia, acidosis (low pH), elevated lactate, triglycerides, ketones, and free fatty acids. A liver biopsy indicates high glycogen content with normal structure, and enzyme assays reveal markedly low levels of glucose-6-phosphatase. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Von Gierke’s disease

 

Option A:

 

Von Gierke’s disease, also known as Glycogen Storage Disease Type Ia, is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, which is crucial for the final step of gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis. This deficiency leads to the inability to convert glycogen into glucose, resulting in severe hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia (elevated triglycerides and free fatty acids), and ketosis. The liver biopsy findings of high glycogen content with normal structure, alongside the clinical presentation of an enlarged liver, frequent hypoglycemic episodes, and the specific enzyme deficiency, strongly support the diagnosis of Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Anderson’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type IV): Characterized by abnormal glycogen with a branched structure, leading to liver cirrhosis, but not typically presenting with hypoglycemia or the specific metabolic abnormalities seen in Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option C. Cori’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type III): Involves a deficiency in the debranching enzyme, leading to abnormal glycogen structure and mild hypoglycemia, but not as severe as in Von Gierke’s disease.

 

Option D. Pompe’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type II): Caused by a deficiency in the lysosomal acid alpha-glucosidase, leading to glycogen accumulation in lysosomes, particularly affecting muscle tissue, not primarily associated with hypoglycemia or liver enlargement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Von Gierke’s disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type Ia) through its hallmark features of hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia, and hepatomegaly due to a deficiency in glucose-6-phosphatase.

 

Affected tissue: Liver and kidney 

 

Clinical features: large quantities of glycogen are formed and stored in hepatocytes, renal and intestinal mucosa cells. The liver and kidneys become enlarged. Abnormalities of lipids may lead to xanthoma formation. Uric acid is often elevated and may cause clinical gout. Galactose, fructose, and glycerol are metabolised to lactate. The elevated blood lactate levels cause metabolic acidosis.

 

Treatment: Blood loss may require oral iron. Treatment of hyperuricaemia and pyelonephritis protect renal function. Diazoxide to maintain blood glucose has been disappointing. Liver transplantation for primary disease or for hepatocellular carcinoma seems effective.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 105 – Page No 3441-3446

questions.text: Madhuri, an 11-year-old girl, presents with joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the hips and knees, and reports that her urine turns dark upon air exposure and has a peculiar odor. Physical examination shows pigmented areas on her skin, and laboratory tests reveal elevated levels of homogentisic acid in her urine. Based on these clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis and its mode of inheritance?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alkaptonuria and Autosomal Recessive

 

Option D:

 

Alkaptonuria is a rare autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase.

 

Clinical features of Alkaptonuria:

 

  • Joint pain and stiffness, particularly affecting the spine and large joints
  • Dark pigmentation of the ears, sclera, and nails
  • Development of small, bluish-black spots on the ears
  • Difficulty breathing on exertion
  • Valvular heart disease
  • Renal stones
  • Urine turns dark upon exposure to air due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in affected individuals
  • Elevated levels of homogentisic acid in blood tests due to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in connective tissues such as cartilage, tendons, and ligaments, leading to the formation of dark pigment known as "ochronosis".

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Alkaptonuria and Autosomal Dominant: This is incorrect; alkaptonuria is autosomal recessive.

 

Option B. Phenylketonuria and Autosomal Dominant: This is incorrect; PKU is autosomal recessive and is not associated with joint pain or urine darkening.

 

Option C. Phenylketonuria and Autosomal Recessive: Although PKU is autosomal recessive, it does not cause urine to darken or joint pain, making this option incorrect for the given clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alkaptonuria is characterized by a deficiency in the enzyme homogentisate dioxygenase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which can cause darkening of the urine upon exposure to air and joint pain due to ochronosis (buildup of homogentisic acid in connective tissues). The pigmentation found on physical examination further supports this diagnosis. Alkaptonuria is inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 103 – Page No 3149-3150

questions.text: A 9-month-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency department due to multiple episodes of loose stools. The child appears dehydrated, with a dry mouth, but drinks water eagerly when offered. Following the administration of oral rehydration solution (ORS) according to protocol, further examination reveals photosensitivity and an ataxic gait. The mother reports a family history of two siblings with similar symptoms, though she and her husband are unaffected. Based on the clinical findings and family history, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hartnup Disease

 

Option B:

 

Hartnup Disease is a Autosomal Recessive disorder, which has the clinical findings similar to Pellagra. The similarities like Dermatitis (photosensitive rash), diarrhoea and can lead to Dementia.

 

  • Defect:  Intestinal and renal tubular reabsorption defect of the neutral amino acids (alanine, valine, threonine, leucine, isoleucine, phenylalanine, tyrosine, tryptophan, histidine, glycine) Tryptophan deficiency leads to nicotinic acid and serotonin deficiency.
  • Clinical finding: Photodermatitis, cerebellar ataxia; often asymptomatic
  • Diagnosis: High levels of neutral amino acids in urine low levels of neutral amino acids in plasma.
  • Therapy: Nicotinamide, sun protection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Alkaptonuria results from the deficiency of Homogentisate oxidase and has a clinical feature of changing of urine colour and Ochronosis.

 

Option C: Phenylketonuria results from the deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase and has clinical features of blond hair and skin changes.

 

Option D: Maple Syrup Urine Disease has a clinical feature of burnt sugar smell of urine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hartnup disease, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by diarrhea, dehydration, photosensitivity, and neurological symptoms such as ataxia. The family history of similarly affected siblings with unaffected parents supports the autosomal recessive inheritance pattern.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 103 – Page No 3178

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought in by their mother due to a recurrent rash upon sun exposure and the passage of purple-colored urine. Following an examination, the child is diagnosed with Congenital Erythropoietic Porphyria, a disorder of heme biosynthesis. Which of the following is NOT a feature of Congenital Erythropoietic Porphyria?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clear Cornea

 

Option C:

 

Congenital Erythropoietic Porphyria (CEP) is characterized by the accumulation of porphyrins leading to skin sensitivity to sunlight, resulting in blisters, erosion, and scarring of the skin. Erythrodontia (red-stained teeth under UV light) and mutilation and disfigurement due to skin damage are well-documented features. Osteodystrophy, which involves bone abnormalities, can also occur due to the accumulation of porphyrins in bone tissue.

 

The cornea typically remains unaffected directly by the porphyrins, which accumulate in various tissues due to CEP. However, secondary complications from severe facial and eyelid damage can potentially affect the eyes. Therefore, "Clear Cornea" is the correct choice as it is not a direct feature of CEP.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Osteodystrophy: Bone abnormalities can occur in CEP due to porphyrin accumulation.

 

Option B. Erythrodontia: This refers to reddish-brown discoloration of the teeth, a hallmark sign of CEP, caused by the deposition of porphyrins in dental tissues.

 

Option D. Mutilation and Disfigurement: Severe skin damage from photosensitivity reactions can lead to significant mutilation and disfigurement in CEP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Congenital erythropoietic porphyria:

 

Enzyme defect: Uroporphyrinogen III cosynthase.

 

Characteristic features - It is a rare congenital disorder. Mostly contained in erythropoietic tissues (bone). Clinical features include;
 

  • Severe cutaneous photosensitivity with blistering and increased friability of the skin over light-exposed areas.
  • The first manifestation is often pink-to-dark red discoloration of the urine.
  • Porphyrin deposition may lead to corneal ulcers and scarring,
  •  reddish-brown discoloration of the teeth (erythrodontia), and
  • Bone loss and/or expansion of the bone marrow.
  • Mutilation and Disfigurement.

 

The diagnosis of CEP in a proband with suggestive clinical and biochemical findings is most commonly established by identification of biallelic pathogenic variants in UROS.

Treatment of manifestations: There is no specific treatment for the photosensitivity. Currently, the only effective management is prevention of blistering by avoidance of sun and light exposure.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 110 – Page No 3656-3662

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to a pediatric outpatient department by his mother, who is concerned about her child's eyes, which have been showing excessive tearing, redness, and sensitivity to light for the past few weeks. She also mentions that her baby seems to be in pain when touching his feet. On examination, the pediatrician observes nonpruritic hyperkeratotic plaques on the soles of the infant's feet, a finding that is unusual and concerning. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of tyrosine in the blood (hypertyrosinemia) and increased 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid in the urine. Given these clinical features and laboratory findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tyrosinemia type 2

 

Option B:

 

Tyrosinemia type 2 (A/K/A richner hanhart syndrome/oculocutaneous tyrosinemia)

 

Clinical features:

 

  • Ocular manifestation: excessive tearing, redness, pain and photophobia.
  • Skin manifestation: painful, nonpruritic hyperkeratotic plaques on soles and palms (seen in adults).

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Hypertyrosinemia(20-50mg/dl)
  • Elevated 4 hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid in urine.

 

Elevated 4 hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid in urine has a significance in diagnosis of Tyrosinemia type 2

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Tyrosinemia type 1 is characterized by liver and kidney dysfunction, neurological crises, and a cabbage-like odor, but not typically by the skin and ocular findings seen in Tyrosinemia type II.

 

Option C: Tyrosinemia type 3 is very rare and typically presents with neurological symptoms; the characteristic skin and ocular features of Tyrosinemia type II are absent.

 

Option D: Tyrosinemia type 4 is not a recognized classification within the medical community for tyrosinemia, making it an incorrect option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tyrosinemia type II (Richner-Hanhart syndrome) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency, leading to elevated tyrosine and 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvic acid levels. Tyrosinemia type I involves liver and renal issues, while type III is associated with neurological symptoms, distinguishing them from type II. Tyrosinemia type IV is not recognized.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st Edition, Chapter 103 – Page No 3143 -3153

choices.text: Alkaptonuria and ferric chloride urine test
Phenylketonuria and ferric chloride urine test

questions.text: A worried mother rushes her 1-year-old son to the emergency department of a district hospital in India, reporting that her child has just experienced a convulsive episode. She mentions that the child was healthy at birth and reached early developmental milestones on time, but she has been increasingly concerned about his slow growth and a persistent rash that she describes as similar to eczema. Upon examination, the emergency physician notes the distinctive eczematous rash and also detects a "mousy" odor in the child's urine, raising suspicion for a metabolic disorder. Given the combination of developmental concerns, seizure, eczematoid rash, and characteristic urine odor, which condition is most likely, and how should the diagnosis be confirmed?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Phenylketonuria and ferric chloride urine test

 

Option C:

 

Classic Phenylketonuria-it is due to defect in phenylalaninie hydroxylase (PAH).

 

Normal at birth, intellectual disability develops gradually if infant remains untreated.

 

CLINICAL FEATURES-

 

  • Lighter in complexion (compared to their siblings)
  • Seborrheic or eczematoid rash.
  • Musty or mousy ordor
  • NEUROLOGOCAL signs: seizures, spasticity, hyperreflexia and tremors
  • Maxillae with widely spaced teeth and growth retardation.

 

DIAGNOSIS-

 

  • Guthries test
  • Ferric chloride urine test
  • Increased Blood phenylalanine(normal:2-6mg/dl)

 

Explanation:

 

Alkaptonuria (Options A and B) is a different metabolic disorder characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid, leading to darkening of the urine upon standing and ochronosis (bluish-black discoloration of connective tissue), but it does not present with the clinical features described in the question, such as eczematoid rash and mousy odor urine.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Phenylketonuria, a treatable metabolic disorder, and the simple diagnostic tests like the ferric chloride urine test is used in initial screening, particularly in areas where more sophisticated diagnostic facilities may not be readily available.

 

Ref: Nelson 21st edition, Chapter 103 – Page No 3178
